awd_titl_txt: Complex Acid-Base Chemistry in Minimal Solvation Environments - The Case of Atmospheric New Particle Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, which is jointly funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-A program of the Chemistry Division and the Atmospheric Chemistry Program of the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Science, Professor Christopher Johnson of Stony Brook University is developing a quantitative description of the fundamental molecular interactions involved in the formation of aerosol particles directly from atmospheric gases. This process accounts for a significant fraction of aerosol particles in the atmosphere.  The underlying mechanisms governing aerosol particle formation are not well understood, leading to uncertainty about their impact on climate change. Due to the sub-nanometer size of newly formed particles, it is difficult to study them using conventional measurements. New techniques to create these particles are combined with recently developed laser spectroscopy methods to investigate the chemistry driving the formation of these particles. The results aid the refinement of models of new particle formation that can be used to improve weather and climate models. In the course of performing this work, young researchers from high school through graduate school are involved in the design, construction, and modification of sophisticated instrumentation and analysis tools.

This project focuses on the development of a new understanding of acid-base chemistry with minimal or no solvent. Though acid-base chemistry in solvents is well understood, new particle formation occurs largely via acid-base chemistry in air, and the role of water vapor in particle formation has not been well established. Clusters of a few acid and base molecules, chosen from those expected to play a role in new particle formation, are generated in a mass spectrometer and studied one specific composition at a time. In ion traps, clusters are exposed to atmospheric trace vapors and their growth is determined by mass spectrometry. Each cluster composition is characterized structurally using vibrational spectroscopy and energetically using temperature-controlled ion traps. These results reveal the energetic factors driving growth, how molecules arrange in the particle, the role of proton transfer between the acids and bases, and whether atmospheric vapors integrate into the acid-base salt structure or bind to its surface.  The results aid the refinement of models of new particle formation that can be used to improve weather and climate models.

por.por_cntn:
The Johnson research group, supported by NSF funding, has investigated the structural patterns present in molecular clusters known to be involved in atmospheric new particle formation (NPF).  NPF is a key process leading to climate-impacting atmospheric aerosols, but unknowns in their formation and growth mechanisms are major uncertainties in global climate models.  Since NPF is difficult to directly study at the molecular level, much work to predict their growth rates is done computationally.  Cluster structures are key input parameters to these computational models, but they are difficult to determine and validate.  The Johnson group has used vibrational spectroscopy to identify patterns of linkages between molecules in these clusters that determine the cluster structure.  We have also developed qualitative rules to predict the number and type of these linkages present, and developed and validated techniques to generate these clusters with a high degree of control.  These studies serve as benchmarks for computational efforts to model the structures of these clusters and reveal which structural patterns require more investigation as particularly active sites for growth.

Clusters of ammonia or amines and sulfuric acid have been widely studied as key seeds for the growth of particles in NPF.  We have used mass spectrometry to isolate clusters of these vapors with exact specificity, allowing us to track the growth process with molecule-by-molecule detail and tracking the structural changes of the clusters as each new molecule is added.  For these studies to be relevant, we needed to develop and validate a method for generating clusters that accurately reproduce those found in gold standard atmospheric simulation experiments.  We have found that the exchange of amines in place of ammonia, which is known to accelerate NPF, necessarily causes structural changes that force more interaction between sulfuric acid molecules.  These interactions are increasingly common as the cluster size increases and exclude the presence of water in the cluster.   This water is found to reside on the surface of the cluster rather than dissolving the core and only a few water molecules are likely to be found on these clusters in the ambient atmosphere.  The amount of water can be predicted from simple counting rules knowing the structure of the cluster and is consistent with theoretical predictions.  These observations suggest that the fastest growing clusters are likely to be the least hydrated, raising significant questions about the role of water in NPF.

A number of young scientists played key roles in these studies: one postdoctoral associate, three graduate students, five undergraduate students, and one high school student made notable contributions.  Each of these scientists received training in atmospheric science, laser spectroscopy, quantum mechanics, computer programming and data analysis, and instrumentation.  All studies were carried out on a home-built instrument designed and constructed by the PI, two graduate students, and two undergraduates, developing skills that are highly valued in scientific research and development.  Three of the undergraduates are currently enrolled in Ph.D. programs in Chemistry at major U.S. research universities.  These results and their impact have been disseminated to the public by the PI and graduate students in a series of seminars open to general audiences or undergraduate students.  The PI has adapted data and analyses used in this work in his newly-developed Computing in Chemistry course, which teaches practical computer programming and numerical analysis skills to advanced undergraduates and graduate students.
